title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — On a night where offensive artistry was scarce, David Robinson authored a defensive masterpiece for the ages.

The San Antonio Spurs, powered not by flash but by fundamental force, grinded out a 91-79 victory over the Indiana Pacers. The final score, however, was a mere footnote to the historic individual performance that unfolded in the paint. Robinson, the Spurs’ stalwart center, didn't just protect the rim; he annexed it, swatting away a staggering 11 Indiana shot attempts.

The Pacers’ offense, typically fluid, was perpetually disrupted by the looming presence of "The Admiral." Every drive to the basket was met with hesitation, every interior pass fraught with peril. Robinson’s 11 blocks were not just statistics; they were systemic demolitions of Indiana’s game plan, fueling the Spurs' transition game and demoralizing a potent opponent.

While Robinson’s defensive dominance set the tone, his 20 points and 8 rebounds provided the essential, steady production for a San Antonio team that won with grit over glamour. Sean Elliott chipped in 18 points, but the night belonged to the man in the middle.

For Indiana, the frustration was palpable. Reggie Miller, the league’s premier marksman, was held to a mere 7 points, his opportunities limited by the collapsing defense anchored by Robinson. Rik Smits led the Pacers with 17 points, but found no refuge in the lane against the defensive titan.

In a league often defined by high-flying offensive exploits, this was a throwback to a different kind of glory. David Robinson’s 11-block tour de force was a defensive clinic, a one-man wall that secured a victory and carved his name into the record books on a night where a single, monumental stat told the entire story.
